title: Does the copyright of a book extend to any and all foreign languages into which the book might be translated in the future? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes; a translation of a work is considered to be a "derivative work" under US Copyright law.  As such, to have independent copyright status, the work must be sufficiently "transformative" to be its own independent, creative work.  A word-for-word translation of an English text to Spanish probably would not be sufficiently "transformative"; an interpretive translation of The Aenid from the original Greek into a narrative form might (disregarding that The Aenid is in the public domain -- it's just an example).
